head.title: Advertising to the Young, At Whose Ultimate Cost?

hedline.hl1: Advertising to the Young, At Whose Ultimate Cost?

abstract.p: Laura Shultz letter responds to Fred Brock's July 2 Seniority column on advertising industry's targeting of young consumers, despite growing wealth and numbers of older consumers; points out that baby-boomer women make most day-to-day purchasing decisions for their families (M)

block.p: In ''A Madison Avenue Fantasy,'' (Seniority, July 2), Fred Brock discussed the advertising industry's continuing emphasis on young consumers, despite the greater wealth and increasing numbers of older adults. The column drew varied responses from readers.

In ''A Madison Avenue Fantasy,'' (Seniority, July 2), Fred Brock discussed the advertising industry's continuing emphasis on young consumers, despite the greater wealth and increasing numbers of older adults. The column drew varied responses from readers.
The column expressed what I've been feeling lately -- that I am virtually ignored by the TV networks.

The show ''Survivor'' is a big hit with my 13-year-old son, but is a real dud for this 49-year-old. Wake up Madison Avenue! Millions of baby-boomer women still make most of the purchasing decisions for our families on a daily basis.
You ignore us at your own peril!
